summary: enable fetch of dynamic metadata using compression
description: unlike the idp the sp does not request dynamic metadata using the accept-encoding header to indicate that it can accept compressed data
this means that even if an mdq server has a compressed version of the metadata available it will not be sent
this will result in significantly larger transfers relatively speaking although as these documents are typically small relative to traditional aggregates the saving may not be large in absolute terms

for reference in the uk federation the smallest metadata documents average and compress to an average of the size uncompressed is the largest metadata documents average and compress to an average of the size uncompressed is the uk federation may or may not be unusual in having such large individual entities in this case with large numbers of it is hard to know whether the extra cpu cost of decompression is worth the reduced transfer size but i think i'd prefer to see it deferring to the mdq server by requesting compressed metadata and letting the server reply with uncompressed data if it was costly to produce

decompression is typically much faster than compression so even if the mdq server compresses needlessly it shouldn't result in a performance penalty and handling additional network packets isn't free either of failing that we could retain the current default but allow compression to be enabled by an explicit setting
this would probably result in most people not bothering of course so it's not my preferred route

we ran into the same problem with xmlsectool and the idp see and but the solution adopted in those cases of setting an application-wide system property prior to initialising the santuario library will not work for the mda is a framework and should not modify global behaviour in that way
the mda probably isn't going to be invoked in such a way that the property can be reliably set before santuario's initialisation
the result of that change is to remove the line separators entirely so still involves a change in behaviour
i think the correct approach here is to document the change in behaviour and the potential use of the system property by the invoker to change the behaviour globally

mda users may need to tweak the output by stripping crs to get the same output as they had before if it matters to them the ukf already runs such a normaliser for the cases in which the mda is running under windows and text files have those separators so where's the bug in the mda's tests which are running up against the fact that the cr is inserted as text and because it is not does not get stripped out prior to comparison with the expected text

summary: design and implementation of a new nameid generation facility

i'd like to be able to configure this outside the resolver and use an explicit nameid generation plugin that would be configured alongside the new layer
i envision in the general case a single default plugin that knows how to encode string or attributes

one or more attribute ids would be supplied to source the data for the plugin
in the case of transients we could consider just building a plugin that generates that kind of nameid and wouldn't have to be sourced from the resolver at all

the whole thing would be a of formats to plugins and the complex format selection logic we do today would be maintained but would just look up plugins in the map test the predicate and then run the first one that applies and can succeed

summary: shibd leaks file handles after rotating logs and touching
description: as outlined in the nativesplogrotation page shibd can be told to reload its log files by rotating them and then touching on the next request that arrives this will then cause shibd to reload and its log files

it took me a while to figure out that the file handles will only be reloaded on the next request that comes in maybe this could be documented unfortunately it looks like the issue from is still in play here any appender that is not attached to the root category does not get closed and leaves leftover file handles eventually causing shibd to run into the open file handle limit

this is a problem for default shibboleth installations since shibd.logger includes two such categories and logrotate.conf sample before logrotate after logrotate at least one request to shibd note that shibd.log and were properly reloaded but the old file handles for signature.log and transaction.log were left dangling

i tested suggestion of inserting a call to in but that makes no difference since calling the same removeallappenders cleanup function that was already getting called anyway when individual categories get reloaded

the root cause here seems to be that there is no way in to actually clean up any appenders as they are all attached as to their categories and therefore never get cleaned up when a category is reloaded or deleted

presumably this is done to avoid double deletes when an appender is used by multiple categories improves the situation for by making the root category own its appenders and thus clean them up on reload but the issue remains for ones
the only proper fix i see is for to fix their appender pointer ownership issues so that can work properly
in the meantime the workaround for logrotating shibd logs is to use copytruncate so file handles can stay the same and not touch in the postrotate script since there is no more need to

summary: versioned session reads may fail arbitrarily under memcached storage service
description: when using the memcached storage service versioned session reads may fail arbitrarily due to a combination of issues memcachestorageservice::readstring fails to write out the expiration timestamp if a versioned read is used and the stored version is not newer
the logic in storageservicesessioncache does not initialize the lastaccess stack variable prior to passing it as an out parameter to receive the value and assumes it is present after the call
the result is that when a versioned read is done and the value from memcached is not newer the lastaccess variable contains arbitrary stack garbage and causes random session expiration decisions
the particular case i ran into was with the touch handler in at but the same logic is repeated multiple times throughout

i imagine both sides need fixing the memcached storage service should return the expiration timestamp unconditionally as is the case for memorystorageservice and the calling logic should initialize the lastaccess values to consistently cause an expiration decision failure if the storage service did not update them and perhaps log an error if an initial value can be chosen that is known to be impossible/nonsensical and checked for also for future storage service implementations perhaps the storageservice readtext/string contract in xmltooling could be more explicit about which values are and are not expected to be written when faced with versioned reads the documentation on currently reads if only copy back data if newer than supplied version but not clear whether data refers to the value or the expiration timestamp or both

summary: spurious caches out of sync warnings on timed out sessions
description: i recently noticed some odd warnings in the shibd logs of the form warn shibboleth.sessioncache unsuccessful read of session id caches out of sync the caches out of sync suggestion is kind of alarming so i did some digging to better understand what is happening

i found that these warnings happen every time someone tries to access a session that is timed out but not yet from what learned my understanding is that there are two expiry timestamps involved an expires timestamp inside the session data end of total lifetime as computed by at session creation time an expires timestamp on the storageservice record holding the session data moment of inactivity timeout cacheallowance the caches out of sync warning happens when the side has the session stored in its local cache finds still valid when someone tries to access it and thus remotes a touch message to the shibd side to update the inactivity timeout of that session
the touch handler on the shibd side does a read of the session from the storageservice if that read fails it spits out the caches out of sync warning

the problem happens because on the side is checking the lifetime expiry of the session now in whereas the read on the storageservice performed by the touch handler on the shibd side is implicitly checking the inactivity+allowance expiry of the session expiration field of the record holding the result is that if a user accesses a session between inactivity_timeout no issue session is still valid between inactivity_timeout inactivity_timeout+cacheallowance storageservice read succeeds additional timeout logic in touch handler catches the timeout no issue between inactivity_timeout+cacheallowance lifetime storageservice read fails caches out of sync error after lifetime expiry no issue catches the lifetime expiry
my argument is that the warning is misleading there is no cache synchronization problem here just the side checking different expiry timestamps than the side

this is an issue because it blocks new sessions from being created
it can also cause deadlocks which can cause the system to crash
dll deadlock failure required app pool recycles to correct suggestion is to allow session cleanup to be handled at the database level rather than from each web server
also an index on the expires column for the texts and strings tables greatly improves performance for these calls and reducing locking between the delete calls and new session creation

summary: extension of consistentaddress for
description: with the increased usage of we get more and more user reports from users that frequently lose their shibboleth sessions at sps although the inactivity between subsequent requests to the same sp is only a few minutes
this then also often forces them to re-authenticate at the idp after the default inactivity timeout of min is currently mostly mac os x lion users

we found that the cause of this behavior has to with the consistentaddress check and the availability of and if the client and the server both support the two protocols then issues like the one described above may occur with certain os and browsers because these send requests once with and some time later with the algorithm used for the connection setup is nicknamed happy eyeballs it is supposed to improve the connectivity/responsiveness of networks
the behavior of mac os x clients is a bit different from the one used in chrome and firefox that also use the happy eyeballs algorithm
mac os does not prefer but uses the destination/protocol with the lowest round trip time
depending on routing and network load this may be the address at one time and a few minutes later the address

possible solutions against this happy eyeballs side effect with consistentaddress true default are disable on client disable on server disable consistentaddress false all of the above solutions have their limitations and drawbacks
another possible solution could be to extend the sp to and store one address for and each per session identified by session this may mitigate the issue described above
one drawback here could be that this may degrade the security of the extended consistentaddress feature as an attacker probably could misuse it
so we are wondering what developers think of this also to note with sometimes comes a privacy extension that will change the regularly on some clients
although this ip change seems to be rather daily than hourly according to our specialists it still should be taken into account

summary: update relyingpartysecuritypolicyresolver to evaluate anonymous relying party case
description: the affected versions did not have an entry for so i am indicating that here
i have stumbled upon what seems to be a bug in idp that has to do with releasing attributes to anonymous relying parties

my understanding that if the rp is treated as anonymous because no metadata was found for it then no attributes should be released to that rp even if my attribute release policy has rules that permit releasing attributes to that rp
bearing on that assumption thats not what i am seeing

in idp running inside tomcat on a windows environment i had the default defaultrelyingparty block configured and next defined an anonymousrelyingparty block with two profiles for saml2ssoprofile and shibbolethssoprofile
on saml2ssoprofile i made sure attribute statements are included by setting the corresponding property to true
i also set up an anonymous sp and had it pull the idp metadata
to stick the anonymous rp definition on the wiki i gave the idp no sp metadata

my sps entity id is my idps entity is as a consequence what i noticed in the idp logs was that it attempted to look for metadata for my sp and when it found none it used the defaultrelyingparty configuration and failed
it failed because my sp was using a certificate and even though my anonymousrelyingparty was configured to use an annonymouscredential which i had created it never was activated
my suspicion is that the anonymousrelyingparty was not activated because the defaultrelyingparty expressed support for the saml profile in the request

in other words it seemed like regardless of whether or not there is metadata for the rp in question if the default rp config could handle the saml profile request the rp was not considered anonymous and thus its relying party configuration never activated
so to get the anonymous configuration to activate i commented out all profile configurations for the default rp and only left the anonymous rp config activated in the file
this seemed to do the trick as i saw in the logs that the idp used the default relying party configuration but then it found no metadata for the party thus treating it as anonymous
next deliberately i defined a policy to release attributes to my seemingly anonymous rp

my attribute filtering policy originally had the following rule afp:attributefilterpolicy id releasetome afp:policyrequirementrule basic:attributerequesterstring value afp:attributerule attributeid edupersonaffiliation afp:permitvaluerule afp:attributerule attributeid edupersonentitlement afp:permitvaluerule afp:attributerule afp:attributefilterpolicy my understanding was that edupersonaffiliation and edupersonentitltement should not be sent back to the sp because i have no metadata for that sp
however what i noticed was that attributes based on my filtering policy and response were submitted back to the acs url generated from the authn request of the anonymous rp
to take this a step further i generated an authn request with a acs url and submitted that to the idp
logs demonstrated that the idp generated a response activated the filtering policy i had for and attempts to submit the response to the evil acs url
hopefully that description is helpful to help you decide if there is actually a bug in the config or whether i have missed an obvious step

i did mark this jira as a security vulnerability because i think that would report the issue privately and just in case i wanted to privately disclose this info rather than sharing it on the message lists

summary: api changes to bean collection property setters and getters
description: as mentioned in passing in the mda bean api for collection property setters is both complex in some cases handling collections containing null elements although these seldom arise and are not compatible with a lot of the recent java apis and inconsistent sometimes allowing null parameters to represent an empty collection sometimes for which is probably the last time we get to make major changes to the api i'd like to have all bean collection properties adhere to the following contract the setter's parameter will be annotated if the code organically handles a null parameter that's fine but it's no longer part of the contract
the implementation does not have to check for a null parameter and handle it specially and that includes not having to guarantee an npe
the setter's parameter will be annotated as the implementation does not have to check for null elements
the expectation is that passing a collection containing null elements will be likely to result in an npe

the setter's parameter will be annotated as the getter will be annotated as either nonnull or the latter case is expected to be rare as it would only be used in cases where a default empty collection cannot make sense
in that case notempty should also appear on both setter and getter

the getter will be annotated as nonnullelements and the implementation will usually involve a private field of some collection type initialised to an empty unmodifiable collection such as if appropriate the setter will check for lifecycle constraints
the setter will then set field the getter will return field directly

summary: single deployment workflow for an idp with multiple extensions
description: we switch deploy idps with extensions mostly our own but more importantly more than one per idp
installing/updating several extensions on a running idp is where this starts being awkward

each extension has own separate build and deployment pipeline which ultimately drops the jar in and calls all right for one extension but with more there could be several instances of the deployment pipeline running and competing to rebuild the war
moreover removing the previous versions of an extension from is necessary and scripting it is rm and subject to the same concurrency issues
on top of that dependencies from extensions themselves must also be installed more hackish scripting and extensions may ship different/conflicting versions of the same libraries

i would like to unify deployment of an idp with extensions by packaging everything into a war file idp.war and take advantage of dependency management to declare which extensions go in and enforce dependency versions
this should reduce an idp to dropping idp.war in my servlet container
i could achieve this today with maven war overlays insert extension jars and their dependencies or even upgrade idp dependencies spring framework security upgrades for example then repack the war
all of that using dependency management and resolution so i can express which version of which extension/library goes in
this process is declarative reproducible and produces one artifact to deploy which fits nicely into modern pipelines
however this is not an officially supported installation method so like to see more support for this kind of deployment from the project
for example runtime dependencies that are installed by the installer like logback could be declared as dependencies of instead
pushing the idea further in this situation the whole installer and scripts like are no longer needed
likewise system configuration could be packaged inside the war since deployers supposed to modify it

going even further the idp could be shipped as an executable jar with an embedded servlet container la spring boot expecting to find its configuration at this would further simplify deployment no commands to execute especially on container platforms

summary: align refresh child refresh status reporting between metadataproviders and attributeresolvers
description: this springs from a side conversation in it turns out that both the metadataprovider service and the attribute resolver service both have reloadable subsystems

metadata providers can track lastsuccessfulreloadinstant lastreloadattemptinstant rootvaliduntil reloadfailurecause the reloadable metadata providers use this to control whether a metadata lookup should trigger a reload

are attribute resolver tracks lastfail the attribute resolver uses this to work out whether it is in a failed status thus whether the failover connector is active and for how long it needs to remain this is all very good

but then we come to status reporting and each of these getplugged into the gauges we export and are also exported to status.jsp this came to our attention because status.jsp dives into the attribute resolver to grab the data connectors to grab the last fail time for each data connector
then it dives into the metadata providers for the above which at least are usefully combined into a refreshablemetadatinstant

this is all useful information we need to make it available buti don't like that the attribute resolver exports its data connectors and i don't like ir that the status page assumes that only data connectors can fail
i can live with it but i'd be happier if both the attribute resolver and the metadata resolver exported a set<reloadablechild where reloadablechild was some sort of glomming together of the above two
this would devolve the work out of from the metrics and the status page and into the resolvers which is kinda where they but i have to be leery of over complication
and although the basic ideas are similar the details of the implementations differ not least because metadata providers cascade data connectors don't

summary: defaults to insecure cookies

the configuration entry is documented can easily be changed but i find such default very dangerous
the idp is already configuring the session cookies as httponly great we are getting this protection
but i find it very scary that with the default settings the browser would leak the idp session cookie over a plain http connection if tricked into opening one
and many idps might be listening on port just to redirect to https and the damage would be done
i see documentation mentions the setting at and the latter admitting the default is mostly an accident but i think the current state is very dangerous
i know how the project approaches changes to default values
thinking of either changing the default or at least making it very prominent in the documentation that this setting should be changed
just gone through contacting all idps in my federation to update the setting in all deployments the default had gone completely unnoticed
leaving up to the project how this gets addressed contacted my federation and share privately with other operators

summary: deprecate dependency
description: this case springs from in which we opened the can of worms that was sourceattributeid and dependency these two examples were quoted as valid now that is done these produce warnings
but the question arose as to whether we actually meant this capability or whether it was an unintended circumstance from conflating two or possible three ideas into a general purpose syntax
there are three different ideas at play here the concept of a dependency
a resolver plugin which should be run before this one is

this is a programming artefact and i dont think it is interesting to the deployer yea i could construct a case where a scripted resolver affected the context to pass information on to another scripted furthermore it was to me confusing since i tended to supply the transitive closure of the dependencies which from the above could ended up adding attributes from a dataconnector which i want

the input attribute for those resolvers which require a single input computedid simple mapped scoped nameid the input environment for those connectors which might want to look at more attributes i can only think of scripted these three concepts were somewhat inelegantly stuffed into two buttons dependency and sourceattributeid which results in something which is reasonably intuitive but which creaks at the edges
it was the confusion between the second two bullets above which provoked and the messy explosion of my mind when i discovered the edges which provokes this case

ill also add that there are multiple resolvers out there for which dependency is meaningless and the documentation has to carry warning about this always a red flag so i took an ai to worry about this

my conclusion is that we actually need to be explicit about the second two bullets and to remove the first its an implementation detail and given the second two the implementation can deduce the so the long term proposal is remove the dependency element entirely and replace it by one of the two following with these only allowed as children for those types which make sense

sourceattribute attributename=attributename use these for the case inputattributes name=attributenameordataconnectorname we could alias sourceattributeid=foo to be sourceattribute if we wanted youd get one or the other not both this makes it possible to configure such disasters as the above but their meaning would be explicit i believe that we can make this and the old style configuration coexist and then to pull the handle on the old style and remove the warnings from since we no longer need to warn about what is however im not sure that we really need to do this

it clarifies a configuration which most people seem to find trouble free otoh it does allow the conflation of attributes values into a single output with an obvious syntax if we think that is for now ill target this at future
if we decide to do this we probably need to schedule it over two or three minor and one major release n.n add the new function and document deprecate the old style remove the old style
but do we care enough it really ends up as pointless for our customers

for completeness i did do some thinking about actually adding the attribute id to the dependency to make the dataconnector inheritance explicit but i believe that it adds confusion whilst not stopping the accidental weirdness above so gains us nothing that already covered by the warning from

summary: consider making abractpkixtrustengine::checkentitynames virtual
description: abstractpkixtrustengine::checkentitynames currently matches the configured key names against different properties of the certificate to be checked to decide whether it is acceptable to continue to the pkix validation stage the full subject dn the last cn rdn the set of subjectalternatenames we are running a shibboleth sp instance that interacts with an idp with peculiar signature certificate naming conventions for which none of the above methods work the idp in question uses signature certificates with subject dns of the form and so on
each time a key rollover happens a new certificate is issued and the rdn is incremented
there are no subject alternate names in the signature certs
because the full dn changes on every rollover and because the last cn rdn is the one and not the one none of the default name matching options work for this idp
asking the organization to change their naming convention is not a likely option in this case as this convention is deeply ingrained in their certificate ecosystem

incidentally the organization documented method for checking the subject dn is to verify that the dn has the suffix happy to patch pkixtrustengine and run a custom build to make that happen but this requires overriding abstractpkixtrustengine::checkentitynames which is currently not possible because it is not virtual

i can patch the method to be virtual in xmltooling as well but then i have to maintain two separate patches for two separate codebases that are mutually dependent which is cumbersome and things will fail silently if i ever forget to apply the xmltooling patch when building therefore would you be willing to consider making abstractpkixtrustengine::checkentitynames virtual so that users of xmltooling can override it without having to patch xmltooling itself i realize that this constitutes an abi change and is therefore not likely to happen any time soon but it would simplify things for these kind of use cases

summary: metadata provider should check validity before replacing old metadata

summary: problem calling virtual functions from base class constructors
description: since at least of sunstudio running unit tests crashes in a test case that clones an authenticationstatement

the crash shows a stack trace that isn't possible and the this pointer changes in the debugger across calls such that the compiler seems to be trashing the object in some way when it executes the call
i've traced it to the use of virtual methods inside base class constructors in this case subjectstatementimpl calling setsubject which calls a virtual releasedom method
moving that down to the subclass constructor fixes the crash
it should be possible to rework these clone operations as two stages one to initialize an empty object via copy constructor and then an internal clone method that actually copies the content
